ai-sn12:4.1.2_0: “Mendicants, Vipassī the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha had this thought before his awakening, when he was still unawakened but intent on awakening:
ai-sn12:4.1.3_0: ‘Alas, this world has fallen into trouble. It’s born, grows old, dies, passes away, and is reborn,
ai-sn12:4.1.4_0: But I don’t understand the escape from old age and death.
ai-sn12:4.1.5_0: and this escape beyond old age and death?’
ai-sn12:4.2.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.2.2_0: ‘When what exists are there old age and death? What is a condition for old age and death?’
ai-sn12:4.2.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.2.4_0: ‘When rebirth exists there is a condition for old age and death.’
ai-sn12:4.3.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.3.2_0: ‘When what exists is a condition for rebirth?’
ai-sn12:4.3.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.3.4_0: ‘When continued existence exists is a condition for rebirth.’
ai-sn12:4.4.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.4.2_0: ‘When what exists is a condition for continued existence?’
ai-sn12:4.4.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.4.4_0: ‘When grasping there is a condition for continued existence, continued existence is a condition for continued existence.’
ai-sn12:4.5.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.5.2_0: ‘When what exists is a condition for grasping?’
ai-sn12:4.5.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.5.4_0: ‘When craving exists is a condition for grasping. Grasping is a condition for grasping.’
ai-sn12:4.6.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.6.2_0: ‘When what exists is a condition for craving?’
ai-sn12:4.6.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.6.4_0: ‘When feeling exists, there is a condition for craving.’
ai-sn12:4.7.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.7.2_0: ‘When what exists are there what is a condition for feeling?’
ai-sn12:4.7.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.7.4_0: ‘When there is contact, feeling is a condition for feeling.’
ai-sn12:4.8.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.8.2_0: ‘When what exists is a condition for contact?’
ai-sn12:4.8.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.8.4_0: ‘When there are the six sense fields, contact is a condition for contact.’
ai-sn12:4.9.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.9.2_0: ‘When what exists are there the six sense fields? What is a condition for the six sense fields?’
ai-sn12:4.9.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.9.4_0: ‘When name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.’
ai-sn12:4.10.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.10.2_0: ‘When what exists are there name and form? What is a condition for name and form?’
ai-sn12:4.10.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.10.4_0: ‘When consciousness exists name and form are a condition for name and form.’
ai-sn12:4.11.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.11.2_0: ‘When what exists is there consciousness? What is a condition for consciousness?’
ai-sn12:4.11.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.11.4_0: ‘When choices exist there’s consciousness. Choices are a condition for consciousness.’

ai-sn12:4.14.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,

ai-sn12:4.15.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:

ai-sn12:4.15.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,

ai-sn12:4.16.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:

ai-sn12:4.17.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:

ai-sn12:4.17.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.17.4_0: ‘When craving doesn’t exist there’s no grasping. When craving ceases, grasping ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.18.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.18.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no craving? When what ceases do craving ceases?’
ai-sn12:4.18.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.18.4_0: ‘When feeling doesn’t exist there’s no craving. When craving ceases, craving ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.19.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.19.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no feeling? When what ceases do feeling ceases?’
ai-sn12:4.19.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.19.4_0: ‘When there’s no contact. When contact ceases, feeling ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.20.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.20.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no contact? When what ceases does contact cease?’
ai-sn12:4.20.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.20.4_0: ‘When the six sense fields don’t exist there’s no contact. When contact ceases, contact ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.21.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.21.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no six sense fields? When what ceases do the six sense fields cease?’
ai-sn12:4.21.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.21.4_0: ‘When name and form don’t exist there are no name and form. When name and form cease, the six sense fields cease.’
ai-sn12:4.22.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.22.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist are there no name and form? When what ceases do name and form cease?’
ai-sn12:4.22.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,
ai-sn12:4.22.4_0: ‘When consciousness doesn’t exist name and form don’t come to be. When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.’
ai-sn12:4.23.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:
ai-sn12:4.23.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no consciousness? When what ceases does consciousness cease?’
ai-sn12:4.23.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,

ai-sn12:4.24.1_0: Then Vipassī, the one intent on awakening, thought:

ai-sn12:4.24.3_0: Then Prince Vipassī, the comprehension of the awakening, thought,

ai-sn12:51.3.2_0: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.

ai-sn12:63.2.3_0: They had an only child, dear and beloved.
ai-sn12:63.2.4_0: As the couple were crossing the desert their limited quantity of supplies would run out,
ai-sn12:63.2.5_0: and they’d still have the rest of the desert to cross.
ai-sn12:63.2.6_0: Then it would occur to that couple:
ai-sn12:63.2.7_0: ‘Our limited quantity of supplies has run out,
ai-sn12:63.2.8_0: and we still have the rest of the desert to cross.

ai-sn12:63.2.11_0: And as they’d eat their child’s flesh, they’d beat their breasts and cry:
ai-sn12:63.2.12_0: ‘Where are you, our only child? Where are you, our only child?’

ai-sn12:65.1.2_0: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
ai-sn12:65.1.3_0: ‘Alas, this world has fallen into trouble. It’s born, grows old, dies, passes away, and is reborn,
ai-sn12:65.1.4_0: But I don’t understand the escape from old age and death.
ai-sn12:65.1.5_0: and this escape beyond old age and death?’
ai-sn12:65.1.7_0: ‘When what exists are there old age and death? What is a condition for old age and death?’
ai-sn12:65.1.8_0: Now, I was in order to focus on the mind, thinking:
ai-sn12:65.1.9_0: ‘When rebirth exists there is a condition for old age and death.’
ai-sn12:65.2.10_0: What is a condition for name and form?’
ai-sn12:65.2.11_0: Now, I was in order to focus on the mind, thinking:
ai-sn12:65.2.12_0: ‘When consciousness exists name and form are a condition for name and form.’
ai-sn12:65.2.14_0: ‘When what exists is there consciousness? What is a condition for consciousness?’
ai-sn12:65.2.15_0: Now, I was in order to focus on the mind, thinking:
ai-sn12:65.2.16_0: ‘When name and form are conditions for consciousness, name and form are conditions for consciousness.’
ai-sn12:65.3.1_0: and what he had thought, adding:
ai-sn12:65.3.2_0: This consciousness turns back from name and form, and doesn’t go beyond that.
ai-sn12:65.3.3_0: This is the extent to which one may be reborn, grow old, die, pass away, or reappear. That is: name and form are conditions for consciousness.
ai-sn12:65.3.4_0: Consciousness is a condition for name and form.
ai-sn12:65.3.5_0: name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.
ai-sn12:65.3.6_0: ‘The six sense fields are conditions for contact.’ ...
ai-sn12:65.3.7_0: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
ai-sn12:65.3.8_0: ‘Origination, origination.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn12:65.4.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no old age and death?
ai-sn12:65.4.3_0: When what ceases do old age and death cease?’
ai-sn12:65.4.4_0: Now, I was in order to focus on the mind, thinking:
ai-sn12:65.4.5_0: ‘When rebirth doesn’t exist there is no old age and death.
ai-sn12:65.4.6_0: When rebirth ceases old age and death cease.’
ai-sn12:65.4.8_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no rebirth? ...
ai-sn12:65.4.9_0: continued existence doesn’t come to be ...
ai-sn12:65.4.16_0: When what ceases do name and form cease?’
ai-sn12:65.4.17_0: Now, I was in order to focus on the mind, thinking:
ai-sn12:65.4.18_0: ‘When consciousness doesn’t exist name and form don’t come to be.
ai-sn12:65.4.19_0: When consciousness ceases name and form cease.’
ai-sn12:65.5.2_0: ‘When what doesn’t exist is there no consciousness?
ai-sn12:65.5.3_0: When what ceases does consciousness cease?’
ai-sn12:65.5.4_0: Now, I was in order to focus on the mind, thinking:
ai-sn12:65.5.5_0: ‘When name and form don’t exist, there is no consciousness.
ai-sn12:65.5.6_0: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.’
ai-sn12:65.6.1_0: and what he had thought, adding:
ai-sn12:65.6.2_0: I have discovered the path to awakening. That is:
ai-sn12:65.6.3_0: When name and form cease, consciousness ceases.
ai-sn12:65.6.4_0: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
ai-sn12:65.6.6_0: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. ...
ai-sn12:65.6.7_0: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’
ai-sn12:65.6.8_0: ‘Cessation, cessation.’ Such was the vision, knowledge, wisdom, realization, and light that arose in me regarding teachings not learned before from another.
ai-sn12:65.7.1_0: Suppose a person was walking through a forest. They’d see an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by humans in the past.
ai-sn12:65.7.3_0: they’d see an ancient city, an ancient capital, inhabited by humans in the past. It was lovely, complete with parks, groves, lotus ponds, and embankments.
ai-sn12:65.7.4_0: Then that person would inform a king or their minister:
ai-sn12:65.7.5_0: ‘Please sir, you should know this. While walking through a forest I saw an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by humans in the past.
ai-sn12:65.7.6_0: Following it along I saw an ancient city, an ancient capital, inhabited by humans in the past. It was lovely, complete with parks, groves, lotus ponds, and embankments.
ai-sn12:65.7.7_0: Sir, you should rebuild that city!’
ai-sn12:65.7.8_0: Then that king or their minister would have that city rebuilt.
ai-sn12:65.7.9_0: And after some time that city was successful and prosperous and full of people, attained to growth and expansion.
ai-sn12:65.7.10_0: In the same way, I saw an ancient path, an ancient route traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past.
ai-sn12:65.8.1_0: And what is that ancient path, the ancient road traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past?
ai-sn12:65.8.2_0: It’s just this noble eightfold path,
ai-sn12:65.8.3_0: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
ai-sn12:65.8.4_0: This is that ancient path, the ancient road traveled by fully awakened Buddhas in the past.
ai-sn12:65.8.5_0: Following it along, I directly knew old age and death,
ai-sn12:65.8.8_0: and the practice that leads to their cessation.
ai-sn12:65.8.10_0: Following it along, I directly knew rebirth ...
ai-sn12:65.8.20_0: Following it along, I directly knew choices,
ai-sn12:65.8.23_0: and the practice that leads to their cessation.
ai-sn12:65.8.24_0: Having directly known this, I told the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
ai-sn12:65.8.25_0: And that’s how this spiritual life has become successful and prosperous, extensive, popular, widespread, and well proclaimed wherever there are gods and humans.”
ai-sn12:66.1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, where they have a town named Kammāsadamma.
ai-sn12:66.1.8_0: When this was said, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-sn12:66.1.10_0: “But mendicant, how do you perform inner self-examination?”
ai-sn12:66.1.12_0: but the Buddha was not happy with the answer.
ai-sn12:66.2.1_0: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
ai-sn12:66.2.2_0: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
ai-sn12:66.2.3_0: Let the Buddha speak of the inner self-examination. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
ai-sn12:66.2.4_0: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
ai-sn12:66.3.1_0: “Take a mendicant who performs inner self-examination:
ai-sn12:66.3.2_0: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.
ai-sn12:66.3.3_0: But what is the source of this suffering? When what exists do old age and death come to be? And when what does not exist do old age and death not come to be?’
ai-sn12:66.3.5_0: ‘The suffering that arises in the world starting with old age and death takes many and diverse forms.
ai-sn12:66.3.6_0: The source of this suffering is attachment. When attachments exist old age and death come to be. And when attachments do not exist old age and death don’t come to be.’
ai-sn12:66.3.7_0: They understand old age and death, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation.
ai-sn12:66.3.8_0: if they live in line with the teaching.
ai-sn12:66.3.9_0: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of old age and death.
ai-sn12:66.4.2_0: ‘But what is the source of this attachment? When what exists does attachment come to be? And when what does not exist does attachment not come to be?’
ai-sn12:66.4.4_0: ‘The source of this attachment is craving. When craving exists attachments come to be. And when craving doesn’t exist attachments don’t come to be.’
ai-sn12:66.4.5_0: They understand attachments, their origin, their cessation, and the fitting practice for their cessation.
ai-sn12:66.4.6_0: if they live in line with the teaching.
ai-sn12:66.4.7_0: This is called a mendicant who is practicing for the complete ending of suffering, for the cessation of attachments.
ai-sn12:66.5.2_0: ‘But where does that craving arise and where does it settle?’
ai-sn12:66.5.4_0: ‘That craving arises and settles on whatever in the world seems nice and pleasant.
ai-sn12:66.5.5_0: And what seems nice and pleasant?
ai-sn12:66.5.6_0: The eye in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.
ai-sn12:66.5.10_0: The body seems nice and pleasant,
ai-sn12:66.5.11_0: mind in the world seems nice and pleasant, and it is there that craving arises and settles.’
ai-sn12:66.6.1_0: There were ascetics and brahmins of the past who saw the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe.
ai-sn12:66.6.3_0: As their craving grew, their attachments grew.
ai-sn12:66.6.4_0: As their attachments grew, their suffering grew.
ai-sn12:66.6.5_0: And as their suffering grew, they were not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They were not freed from suffering, I say.
ai-sn12:66.7.1_0: There will be ascetics and brahmins in the future who will see the things that seem nice and pleasant in the world as permanent, as pleasurable, as self, as healthy, and as safe.

ai-sn12:66.7.4_0: As their attachments grow, their suffering will grow.
ai-sn12:66.7.5_0: And as their suffering grows, they will not be freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. They will not be freed from suffering, I say.

ai-sn12:67.1.1_0: At one time Venerable Sāriputta and Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita were staying near Benares, in the deer park at Isipatana. ...
ai-sn12:67.1.2_0: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita came out of retreat, went to Venerable Sāriputta,
ai-sn12:67.1.3_0: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
ai-sn12:67.1.3_1: He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:
ai-sn12:67.1.4_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, are old age and death made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.1.5_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, old age and death are not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.1.6_0: Rather, rebirth is a condition for old age and death.”
ai-sn12:67.2.1_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, is rebirth made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.2.2_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, rebirth is not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.2.3_0: Rather, continued existence is a condition for rebirth.”
ai-sn12:67.3.1_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, is continued existence made by oneself? ...” ...
ai-sn12:67.3.6_0: “Are the six sense fields made by oneself? ...” ...
ai-sn12:67.3.7_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, are name and form made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.3.8_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, name and form are not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.3.9_0: Rather, consciousness is a condition for name and form.”
ai-sn12:67.4.1_0: “Well, Reverend Sāriputta, is consciousness made by oneself? Or by another? Or by both oneself and another? Or does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another?”
ai-sn12:67.4.2_0: “No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, consciousness is not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.4.3_0: Rather, name and form are conditions for consciousness.”
ai-sn12:67.5.1_0: “Just now I understood you to say:
ai-sn12:67.5.2_0: ‘No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, name and form are not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor do they arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.5.3_0: Rather, consciousness is a condition for name and form.’
ai-sn12:67.6.1_0: But I also understood you to say:
ai-sn12:67.6.2_0: ‘No, Reverend Koṭṭhita, consciousness is not made by oneself, nor by another, nor by both oneself and another, nor does it arise by chance, not made by oneself or another.
ai-sn12:67.6.3_0: Rather, name and form are conditions for consciousness.’
ai-sn12:67.7.1_0: ... How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”
ai-sn12:67.7.2_0: “Well then, reverend, I shall give you a simile.
ai-sn12:67.7.3_0: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
ai-sn12:67.7.4_0: Suppose there were two firebrands with hot coals.
ai-sn12:67.7.5_0: In the same way, name and form are conditions for consciousness.
ai-sn12:67.7.6_0: Consciousness is a condition for name and form.
ai-sn12:67.7.7_0: name and form are conditions for the six sense fields.
ai-sn12:67.7.8_0: ‘The six sense fields are conditions for contact.’ ...
ai-sn12:67.7.9_0: This is how there is the origin of this whole mass of suffering.
ai-sn12:67.7.10_0: If the first of those bundles of reeds were to be pulled away, the other would collapse.
ai-sn12:67.7.11_0: And if the other were to be pulled away, the first would collapse.
ai-sn12:67.7.12_0: In the same way, name and form cease.
ai-sn12:67.7.13_0: When consciousness ceases, name and form cease.
ai-sn12:67.7.15_0: When the six sense fields cease, contact ceases. ...
ai-sn12:67.7.16_0: This is how there is the end of this whole mass of suffering.”
ai-sn12:67.8.3_0: How well spoken this was by Venerable Sāriputta!
ai-sn12:67.8.4_0: And we can express our agreement with Venerable Sāriputta’s statement on these thirty-six grounds.
ai-sn12:67.9.1_0: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding old age and death, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
ai-sn12:67.9.2_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding old age and death, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
ai-sn12:67.9.3_0: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding old age and death, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.
ai-sn12:67.9.4_0: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment regarding rebirth ...
ai-sn12:67.9.8_0: If you’re not rid of greed for feeling ...
ai-sn12:67.9.14_0: If a mendicant teaches Dhamma for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding ignorance, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who speaks on Dhamma’.
ai-sn12:67.9.15_0: If they practice for disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding ignorance, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who practices in line with the teaching’.
ai-sn12:67.9.16_0: If they’re freed by not grasping by disillusionment, dispassion, and cessation regarding ignorance, they’re qualified to be called a ‘mendicant who has attained extinguishment in this very life’.”
ai-sn12:68.1.1_0: At one time the venerables Musīla, Saviṭṭha, Nārada, and Ānanda were staying near Kosambī in Ghosita’s monastery.
